title: How was Japan before Tang Dynasty? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thank you for the A2A. This is actually a very good/interesting question, despite the disrespect from some previous respondents. Because arguably, if it weren’t for the huge influence from Tang Dynasty through the 遣唐使（けんとうし/Kentōshi）missions, Japan may not have established a centralized government as quickly. And a lot of Japanese “official” garb from the times before, including what ended up as kimono, probably came from Tang Dynasty. Last but not least, we would not have as much Buddhism! At the time Tang Dynasty started in 618 AD, Empress Suiko (推古天皇 Suiko-tennō) was the monarch of Japan. She (yes, she) was the 33rd empress/emperor from 592–628; she was the first of eight women to take on the role of empress regnant. (She lived until 74–75, which seems impressive for that time.) After Empress Kōken (孝謙天皇 Kōken-tennō, reign 749–758 & 764–770), the sixth female tennō, there wasn’t another empress for 859 years, until Empress Meishō (明正天皇 Meishō-tennō, reign 1629-1643). So one could also suspect Tang Dynasty’s influence might have been a patriarchal one (likely due to the Confucian leadership influence, and not because of Buddhism). Japan’s Asuka period (飛鳥時代 Asuka jidai, 538–710), both overlapping and somewhat preceding Tang Dynasty, was a period of artistic, social, and political transformations, largely affected by the arrival of Buddhism from China. This is when the country/region changed its name from Wa (倭) to Nihon (日本), with its government becoming much more centralized. Before then, the area was in a state of constant flux. What existed was Yamatai-koku (邪馬台国) , which is the Sino-Japanese name of an ancient country in Wa (Japan) during the late Yayoi period (BC 300-300 AD). During that time the most successful ruler in the country was Himiko (卑弥呼, 170–248 AD), a shaman queen of Yamatai-koku. Prior to that there was a 70–80 year period of reign by male kings, and after much infighting, they decided on making Himiko the queen. But it wasn’t as though the country was united - it was 30 or so separate regions. Following that, during the Asuka period, Empress Suiko’s nephew, the infamous Prince Shōtoku (聖徳太子 Shōtoku Taishi) , was instrumental in establishing a centralized government. He is credited with promulgating a Seventeen-article constitution, and was an ardent Buddhist. So he is responsible for spreading Buddhism as well. Historians have noted that prior to Himiko’s rule, Japan had sent diplomatic missions to the Western Han commandery in Lelang, Northern Korea, in order to gain recognition, but back then Japanese missions to Chinese dynasties and kingdoms were spaced out over centuries, possibly due to turmoil back home, as stated in the following: “Wa diplomats, however, never called on China on a regular basis. A chronology of Japan-China relations from the first to the ninth centuries reveals this irregularity in the visits of Japanese ambassadors to China. There were periods of frequent contacts as well as of lengthy intervals between contacts.” “The earliest written records about people in Japan are from Chinese sources from this period.  The golden seal said to have been granted to the "King of Wa" by Emperor Guangwu of Han in 57 CE. It is inscribed “King of Na of Wa in Han Dynasty” (漢委奴國王). Wa, the Japanese pronunciation of an early Chinese name for Japan, was mentioned in 57 AD; the Na state of Wa received a golden seal from the Emperor Guangwu of the Later Han Dynasty. This event was recorded in the Hou Han Shu compiled by Fan Ye in the 5th century. The seal itself was discovered in northern Kyūshū in the 18th century.[13] Wa was also mentioned in 257 in the Wei zhi, a section of the San Guo Zhi compiled by the 3rd century scholar Chen Shou.[14]” definition of Yayoi period and synonyms of Yayoi period (English) It's, thus, sound to conclude that there were some significant contacts between Japan and China prior to the Tang Dynasty and that Chinese scholars were prominent in having recorded early Japanese contacts. Although 遣唐使（Kentōshi）missions are most famous since they lasted for nearly 200 years, it’s not as though Empress Suiko (推古天皇) did not interact with China prior to Tang Dynasty. She was known as a very fair ruler who allowed 聖徳太子 (Shōtoku Taishi) to flourish, and she had her own missions (遣隋使/kenzuishi) to Sui Dynasty, hoping for them to recognize Japan’s legitimacy as a country. She sent exchange students along with the mission, just like 遣唐使. She is also responsible for building Hōryū-ji (法隆寺) temple, as she was as much of an advocate for Buddhism as 聖徳太子 (Shōtoku Taishi) . During the Asuka period, nobles ate 古代米 (こだいまい/“ancient rice”):  A typical aristocrats’ meal had things like snapper, abalone, cheese (蘇/so - cow milk was introduced during this period) etc., and sometimes they were said to get too much nutrition, resulting in lifestyle disease.  Source: yamatoji.nara-kankou.or.jp A typical commoners’ meal: Brown rice, salt, seaweed soup, and maybe some boiled vegetables. This hadn’t changed much since the preceding Yayoi period; it was basically “一汁一菜” (one soup one vegetable); sometimes people fainted from malnutrition. Due to the influence of Buddhism, animal meat was often prohibited.  Source: www.juk2.sakura.ne.jp Attire of aristocrats (after interacting with Tang Dynasty, more vivid colors were introduced):   Source: yamatoji.nara-kankou.or.jp Attire of common people (not much color or shape):  Source: www7a.biglobe.ne.jp Residence for the ruling class (model):  Source: www7a.biglobe.ne.jp Residence of common farmers:   Source: www7a.biglobe.ne.jp I’m not enough of a history buff to do this question justice, but I hope I answered some of your question. It’s interesting to know how normal people lived during that time period, too, partly because some of the most gorgeous Buddhist buildings and sculptures were constructed around this period. As with many societies around the world, resources were not well-distributed.
